Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The primary key of the item to be updated. Each element consists of an attribute name and a value for that attribute.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.name: returnValuesOnConditionCheckFailure
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Use ReturnValuesOnConditionCheckFailure to get the item attributes if the Update condition fails. For ReturnValuesOnConditionCheckFailure, the valid values are: NONE, ALL_OLD, UPDATED_OLD, ALL_NEW, UPDATED_NEW.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Name of the table for the UpdateItem request.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.name: updateExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: An expression that defines one or more attributes to be updated, the action to be performed on them, and new value(s) for them.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUntagResourceInput.ht.name: resourceArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUntagResourceInput.ht.abstract: The DynamoDB resource that the tags will be removed from. This value is an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUntagResourceInput.ht.name: tagKeys
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUntagResourceInput.ht.abstract: A list of tag keys. Existing tags of the resource whose keys are members of this list will be removed from the DynamoDB resource.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsOut.name: consumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsOut.abstract: The capacity units consumed by the entire TransactWriteItems operation. The values of the list are ordered according to the ordering of the TransactItems request parameter.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsOut.name: itemCollectionMetrics
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsOut.abstract: A list of tables that were processed by TransactWriteItems and, for each table, information about any item collections that were affected by individual UpdateItem, PutItem, or DeleteItem operations.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.name: clientRequestToken
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.abstract:
Providing a ClientRequestToken makes the call to TransactWriteItems idempotent, meaning that multiple identical calls have the same effect as one single call.

Although multiple identical calls using the same client request token produce the same result on the server (no side effects), the responses to the calls might not be the same. If the ReturnConsumedCapacity> parameter is set, then the initial TransactWriteItems call returns the amount of write capacity units consumed in making the changes. Subsequent TransactWriteItems calls with the same client token return the number of read capacity units consumed in reading the item.

A client request token is valid for 10 minutes after the first request that uses it is completed. After 10 minutes, any request with the same client token is treated as a new request. Do not resubmit the same request with the same client token for more than 10 minutes, or the result might not be idempotent.

If you submit a request with the same client token but a change in other parameters within the 10-minute idempotency window, DynamoDB returns an IdempotentParameterMismatch exception.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.name: returnConsumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.abstract:
Determines the level of detail about provisioned throughput consumption that is returned in the response:

  • INDEXES - The response includes the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation, together with ConsumedCapacity for each table and secondary index that was accessed.

    Note that some operations, such as GetItem and BatchGetItem, do not access any indexes at all. In these cases, specifying INDEXES will only return ConsumedCapacity information for table(s).

  • TOTAL - The response includes only the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation.

  • NONE - No ConsumedCapacity details are included in the response.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.name: returnItemCollectionMetrics
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.abstract: Determines whether item collection metrics are returned. If set to SIZE, the response includes statistics about item collections (if any), that were modified during the operation and are returned in the response. If set to NONE (the default), no statistics are returned.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.name: transactItems
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItemsInp.abstract: An ordered array of up to 25 TransactWriteItem objects, each of which contains a ConditionCheck, Put, Update, or Delete object. These can operate on items in different tables, but the tables must reside in the same AWS account and Region, and no two of them can operate on the same item.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItem.htm.name: conditionCheck
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItem.htm.abstract: A request to perform a check item operation.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsOutpu.name: consumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsOutpu.abstract: If the ReturnConsumedCapacity value was TOTAL, this is an array of ConsumedCapacity objects, one for each table addressed by TransactGetItem objects in the TransactItems parameter. These ConsumedCapacity objects report the read-capacity units consumed by the TransactGetItems call in that table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsOutpu.name: responses
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsOutpu.abstract:
An ordered array of up to 25 ItemResponse objects, each of which corresponds to the TransactGetItem object in the same position in the TransactItems array. Each ItemResponse object contains a Map of the name-value pairs that are the projected attributes of the requested item.

If a requested item could not be retrieved, the corresponding ItemResponse object is Null, or if the requested item has no projected attributes, the corresponding ItemResponse object is an empty Map.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsInput.name: returnConsumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsInput.abstract: A value of TOTAL causes consumed capacity information to be returned, and a value of NONE prevents that information from being returned. No other value is valid.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsInput.name: transactItems
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItemsInput.abstract: An ordered array of up to 25 TransactGetItem objects, each of which contains a Get structure.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItem.html#.name: get
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItem.html#.abstract: Contains the primary key that identifies the item to get, together with the name of the table that contains the item, and optionally the specific attributes of the item to retrieve.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveSpecificati.name: attributeName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveSpecificati.abstract: The name of the TTL attribute used to store the expiration time for items in the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveSpecificati.name: enabled
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveSpecificati.abstract: Indicates whether TTL is to be enabled (true) or disabled (false) on the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveDescription.name: attributeName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveDescription.abstract: The name of the TTL attribute for items in the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveDescription.name: timeToLiveStatus
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveDescription.abstract: The TTL status for the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTagResourceInput.html.name: resourceArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTagResourceInput.html.abstract: Identifies the Amazon DynamoDB resource to which tags should be added. This value is an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTagResourceInput.html.name: tags
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTagResourceInput.html.abstract: The tags to be assigned to the Amazon DynamoDB resource.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTag.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: key
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTag.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: The key of the tag. Tag keys are case sensitive. Each DynamoDB table can only have up to one tag with the same key. If you try to add an existing tag (same key), the existing tag value will be updated to the new value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTag.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: value
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTag.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: The value of the tag. Tag values are case-sensitive and can be null.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: archivalSummary
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: Contains information about the table archive.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: attributeDefinitions
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract:
An array of AttributeDefinition objects. Each of these objects describes one attribute in the table and index key schema.

Each AttributeDefinition object in this array is composed of:

  • AttributeName - The name of the attribute.

  • AttributeType - The data type for the attribute.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: billingModeSummary
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: Contains the details for the read/write capacity mode.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: creationDateTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The date and time when the table was created, in UNIX epoch time format.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: globalSecondaryIndexes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract:
The global secondary indexes, if any, on the table. Each index is scoped to a given partition key value. Each element is composed of:

  • Backfilling - If true, then the index is currently in the backfilling phase. Backfilling occurs only when a new global secondary index is added to the table. It is the process by which DynamoDB populates the new index with data from the table. (This attribute does not appear for indexes that were created during a CreateTable operation.)

    You can delete an index that is being created during the Backfilling phase when IndexStatus is set to CREATING and Backfilling is true. You can’t delete the index that is being created when IndexStatus is set to CREATING and Backfilling is false. (This attribute does not appear for indexes that were created during a CreateTable operation.)

  • IndexName - The name of the global secondary index.

  • IndexSizeBytes - The total size of the global secondary index, in bytes. DynamoDB updates this value approximately every six hours. Recent changes might not be reflected in this value.

  • IndexStatus - The current status of the global secondary index:

    • CREATING - The index is being created.

    • UPDATING - The index is being updated.

    • DELETING - The index is being deleted.

    • ACTIVE - The index is ready for use.

  • ItemCount - The number of items in the global secondary index. DynamoDB updates this value approximately every six hours. Recent changes might not be reflected in this value.

  • KeySchema - Specifies the complete index key schema. The attribute names in the key schema must be between 1 and 255 characters (inclusive). The key schema must begin with the same partition key as the table.

  • Projection - Specifies attributes that are copied (projected) from the table into the index. These are in addition to the primary key attributes and index key attributes, which are automatically projected. Each attribute specification is composed of:

    • ProjectionType - One of the following:

      • KEYS_ONLY - Only the index and primary keys are projected into the index.

      • INCLUDE - Only the specified table attributes are projected into the index. The list of projected attributes is in NonKeyAttributes.

      • ALL - All of the table attributes are projected into the index.

    • NonKeyAttributes - A list of one or more non-key attribute names that are projected into the secondary index. The total count of attributes provided in NonKeyAttributes, summed across all of the secondary indexes, must not exceed 20. If you project the same attribute into two different indexes, this counts as two distinct attributes when determining the total.

  • ProvisionedThroughput - The provisioned throughput settings for the global secondary index, consisting of read and write capacity units, along with data about increases and decreases.

If the table is in the DELETING state, no information about indexes will be returned.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: globalTableVersion
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: Represents the version of global tables in use, if the table is replicated across AWS Regions.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: itemCount
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The number of items in the specified table. DynamoDB updates this value approximately every six hours. Recent changes might not be reflected in this value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: keySchema
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract:
The primary key structure for the table. Each KeySchemaElement consists of:

  • AttributeName - The name of the attribute.

  • KeyType - The role of the attribute:

    • HASH - partition key

    • RANGE - sort key

    The partition key of an item is also known as its hash attribute. The term “hash attribute” derives from DynamoDB’s usage of an internal hash function to evenly distribute data items across partitions, based on their partition key values.

    The sort key of an item is also known as its range attribute. The term “range attribute” derives from the way DynamoDB stores items with the same partition key physically close together, in sorted order by the sort key value.

For more information about primary keys, see Primary Key in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: latestStreamArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the latest stream for this table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: latestStreamLabel
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract:
A timestamp, in ISO 8601 format, for this stream.

Note that LatestStreamLabel is not a unique identifier for the stream, because it is possible that a stream from another table might have the same timestamp. However, the combination of the following three elements is guaranteed to be unique:

  • AWS customer ID

  • Table name

  • StreamLabel

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: localSecondaryIndexes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract:
Represents one or more local secondary indexes on the table. Each index is scoped to a given partition key value. Tables with one or more local secondary indexes are subject to an item collection size limit, where the amount of data within a given item collection cannot exceed 10 GB. Each element is composed of:

  • IndexName - The name of the local secondary index.

  • KeySchema - Specifies the complete index key schema. The attribute names in the key schema must be between 1 and 255 characters (inclusive). The key schema must begin with the same partition key as the table.

  • Projection - Specifies attributes that are copied (projected) from the table into the index. These are in addition to the primary key attributes and index key attributes, which are automatically projected. Each attribute specification is composed of:

    • ProjectionType - One of the following:

      • KEYS_ONLY - Only the index and primary keys are projected into the index.

      • INCLUDE - Only the specified table attributes are projected into the index. The list of projected attributes is in NonKeyAttributes.

      • ALL - All of the table attributes are projected into the index.

    • NonKeyAttributes - A list of one or more non-key attribute names that are projected into the secondary index. The total count of attributes provided in NonKeyAttributes, summed across all of the secondary indexes, must not exceed 20. If you project the same attribute into two different indexes, this counts as two distinct attributes when determining the total.

  • IndexSizeBytes - Represents the total size of the index, in bytes. DynamoDB updates this value approximately every six hours. Recent changes might not be reflected in this value.

  • ItemCount - Represents the number of items in the index. DynamoDB updates this value approximately every six hours. Recent changes might not be reflected in this value.

If the table is in the DELETING state, no information about indexes will be returned.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: provisionedThroughput
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The provisioned throughput settings for the table, consisting of read and write capacity units, along with data about increases and decreases.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: replicas
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: Represents replicas of the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: restoreSummary
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: Contains details for the restore.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: SSEDescription
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The description of the server-side encryption status on the specified table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: streamSpecification
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The current DynamoDB Streams configuration for the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: tableArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: tableId
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: Unique identifier for the table for which the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The name of the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: tableSizeBytes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract: The total size of the specified table, in bytes. DynamoDB updates this value approximately every six hours. Recent changes might not be reflected in this value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.name: tableStatus
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableDescription.html.abstract:
The current state of the table:

  • CREATING - The table is being created.

  • UPDATING - The table is being updated.

  • DELETING - The table is being deleted.

  • ACTIVE - The table is ready for use.

  • INACCESSIBLE_ENCRYPTION_CREDENTIALS - The AWS KMS key used to encrypt the table in inaccessible. Table operations may fail due to failure to use the AWS KMS key. DynamoDB will initiate the table archival process when a table’s AWS KMS key remains inaccessible for more than seven days.

  • ARCHIVING - The table is being archived. Operations are not allowed until archival is complete.

  • ARCHIVED - The table has been archived. See the ArchivalReason for more information.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableAutoScalingDescr.name: tableStatus
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableAutoScalingDescr.abstract:
The current state of the table:

  • CREATING - The table is being created.

  • UPDATING - The table is being updated.

  • DELETING - The table is being deleted.

  • ACTIVE - The table is ready for use.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBStreamSpecification.h.name: streamEnabled
Classes/AWSDynamoDBStreamSpecification.h.abstract: Indicates whether DynamoDB Streams is enabled (true) or disabled (false) on the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBStreamSpecification.h.name: streamViewType
Classes/AWSDynamoDBStreamSpecification.h.abstract:
When an item in the table is modified, StreamViewType determines what information is written to the stream for this table. Valid values for StreamViewType are:

  • KEYS_ONLY - Only the key attributes of the modified item are written to the stream.

  • NEW_IMAGE - The entire item, as it appears after it was modified, is written to the stream.

  • OLD_IMAGE - The entire item, as it appeared before it was modified, is written to the stream.

  • NEW_AND_OLD_IMAGES - Both the new and the old item images of the item are written to the stream.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.name: globalSecondaryIndexes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.abstract: Represents the GSI properties for the table when the backup was created. It includes the IndexName, KeySchema, Projection, and ProvisionedThroughput for the GSIs on the table at the time of backup.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.name: localSecondaryIndexes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.abstract: Represents the LSI properties for the table when the backup was created. It includes the IndexName, KeySchema and Projection for the LSIs on the table at the time of backup.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.name: SSEDescription
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.abstract: The description of the server-side encryption status on the table when the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.name: streamDescription
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.abstract: Stream settings on the table when the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.name: timeToLiveDescription
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableFeatureDet.abstract: Time to Live settings on the table when the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: billingMode
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract:
Controls how you are charged for read and write throughput and how you manage capacity. This setting can be changed later.

  • PROVISIONED - Sets the read/write capacity mode to PROVISIONED. We recommend using PROVISIONED for predictable workloads.

  • PAY_PER_REQUEST - Sets the read/write capacity mode to PAY_PER_REQUEST. We recommend using PAY_PER_REQUEST for unpredictable workloads.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: itemCount
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: Number of items in the table. Note that this is an approximate value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: provisionedThroughput
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: Read IOPs and Write IOPS on the table when the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: tableArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: ARN of the table for which backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: tableCreationDateTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: Time when the source table was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: tableId
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: Unique identifier for the table for which the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: The name of the table for which the backup was created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.name: tableSizeBytes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSourceTableDetails.ht.abstract: Size of the table in bytes. Note that this is an approximate value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.name: consumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The capacity units consumed by the Scan operation. The data returned includes the total provisioned throughput consumed, along with statistics for the table and any indexes involved in the operation. ConsumedCapacity is only returned if the ReturnConsumedCapacity parameter was specified. For more information, see Provisioned Throughput in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.name: count
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The number of items in the response.

If you set ScanFilter in the request, then Count is the number of items returned after the filter was applied, and ScannedCount is the number of matching items before the filter was applied.

If you did not use a filter in the request, then Count is the same as ScannedCount.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.name: items
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.abstract: An array of item attributes that match the scan criteria. Each element in this array consists of an attribute name and the value for that attribute.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.name: lastEvaluatedKey
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The primary key of the item where the operation stopped, inclusive of the previous result set. Use this value to start a new operation, excluding this value in the new request.

If LastEvaluatedKey is empty, then the “last page” of results has been processed and there is no more data to be retrieved.

If LastEvaluatedKey is not empty, it does not necessarily mean that there is more data in the result set. The only way to know when you have reached the end of the result set is when LastEvaluatedKey is empty.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.name: scannedCount
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanOutput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The number of items evaluated, before any ScanFilter is applied. A high ScannedCount value with few, or no, Count results indicates an inefficient Scan operation. For more information, see Count and ScannedCount in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

If you did not use a filter in the request, then ScannedCount is the same as Count.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: attributesToGet
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use ProjectionExpression instead. For more information, see AttributesToGet in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: conditionalOperator
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use FilterExpression instead. For more information, see ConditionalOperator in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: consistentRead
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
A Boolean value that determines the read consistency model during the scan:

  • If ConsistentRead is false, then the data returned from Scan might not contain the results from other recently completed write operations (PutItem, UpdateItem, or DeleteItem).

  • If ConsistentRead is true, then all of the write operations that completed before the Scan began are guaranteed to be contained in the Scan response.

The default setting for ConsistentRead is false.

The ConsistentRead parameter is not supported on global secondary indexes. If you scan a global secondary index with ConsistentRead set to true, you will receive a ValidationException.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: exclusiveStartKey
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
The primary key of the first item that this operation will evaluate. Use the value that was returned for LastEvaluatedKey in the previous operation.

The data type for ExclusiveStartKey must be String, Number or Binary. No set data types are allowed.

In a parallel scan, a Scan request that includes ExclusiveStartKey must specify the same segment whose previous Scan returned the corresponding value of LastEvaluatedKey.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: expressionAttributeNames
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
One or more substitution tokens for attribute names in an expression. The following are some use cases for using ExpressionAttributeNames:

  • To access an attribute whose name conflicts with a DynamoDB reserved word.

  • To create a placeholder for repeating occurrences of an attribute name in an expression.

  • To prevent special characters in an attribute name from being misinterpreted in an expression.

Use the # character in an expression to dereference an attribute name. For example, consider the following attribute name:

  • Percentile

The name of this attribute conflicts with a reserved word, so it cannot be used directly in an expression. (For the complete list of reserved words, see Reserved Words in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide). To work around this, you could specify the following for ExpressionAttributeNames:

  • {"#P":"Percentile"}

You could then use this substitution in an expression, as in this example:

  • #P = :val

Tokens that begin with the : character are expression attribute values, which are placeholders for the actual value at runtime.

For more information on expression attribute names, see Specifying Item Attributes in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: expressionAttributeValues
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
One or more values that can be substituted in an expression.

Use the : (colon) character in an expression to dereference an attribute value. For example, suppose that you wanted to check whether the value of the ProductStatus attribute was one of the following:

Available | Backordered | Discontinued

You would first need to specify ExpressionAttributeValues as follows:

{ ":avail":{"S":"Available"}, ":back":{"S":"Backordered"}, ":disc":{"S":"Discontinued"} }

You could then use these values in an expression, such as this:

ProductStatus IN (:avail, :back, :disc)

For more information on expression attribute values, see Condition Expressions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: filterExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
A string that contains conditions that DynamoDB applies after the Scan operation, but before the data is returned to you. Items that do not satisfy the FilterExpression criteria are not returned.

A FilterExpression is applied after the items have already been read; the process of filtering does not consume any additional read capacity units.

For more information, see Filter Expressions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: indexName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract: The name of a secondary index to scan. This index can be any local secondary index or global secondary index. Note that if you use the IndexName parameter, you must also provide TableName.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: limit
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract: The maximum number of items to evaluate (not necessarily the number of matching items). If DynamoDB processes the number of items up to the limit while processing the results, it stops the operation and returns the matching values up to that point, and a key in LastEvaluatedKey to apply in a subsequent operation, so that you can pick up where you left off. Also, if the processed dataset size exceeds 1 MB before DynamoDB reaches this limit, it stops the operation and returns the matching values up to the limit, and a key in LastEvaluatedKey to apply in a subsequent operation to continue the operation. For more information, see Working with Queries in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: projectionExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
A string that identifies one or more attributes to retrieve from the specified table or index. These attributes can include scalars, sets, or elements of a JSON document. The attributes in the expression must be separated by commas.

If no attribute names are specified, then all attributes will be returned. If any of the requested attributes are not found, they will not appear in the result.

For more information, see Specifying Item Attributes in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: returnConsumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
Determines the level of detail about provisioned throughput consumption that is returned in the response:

  • INDEXES - The response includes the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation, together with ConsumedCapacity for each table and secondary index that was accessed.

    Note that some operations, such as GetItem and BatchGetItem, do not access any indexes at all. In these cases, specifying INDEXES will only return ConsumedCapacity information for table(s).

  • TOTAL - The response includes only the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation.

  • NONE - No ConsumedCapacity details are included in the response.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: scanFilter
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use FilterExpression instead. For more information, see ScanFilter in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: segment
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
For a parallel Scan request, Segment identifies an individual segment to be scanned by an application worker.

Segment IDs are zero-based, so the first segment is always 0. For example, if you want to use four application threads to scan a table or an index, then the first thread specifies a Segment value of 0, the second thread specifies 1, and so on.

The value of LastEvaluatedKey returned from a parallel Scan request must be used as ExclusiveStartKey with the same segment ID in a subsequent Scan operation.

The value for Segment must be greater than or equal to 0, and less than the value provided for TotalSegments.

If you provide Segment, you must also provide TotalSegments.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: select
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
The attributes to be returned in the result. You can retrieve all item attributes, specific item attributes, the count of matching items, or in the case of an index, some or all of the attributes projected into the index.

  • ALL_ATTRIBUTES - Returns all of the item attributes from the specified table or index. If you query a local secondary index, then for each matching item in the index, DynamoDB fetches the entire item from the parent table. If the index is configured to project all item attributes, then all of the data can be obtained from the local secondary index, and no fetching is required.

  • ALL_PROJECTED_ATTRIBUTES - Allowed only when querying an index. Retrieves all attributes that have been projected into the index. If the index is configured to project all attributes, this return value is equivalent to specifying ALL_ATTRIBUTES.

  • COUNT - Returns the number of matching items, rather than the matching items themselves.

  • SPECIFIC_ATTRIBUTES - Returns only the attributes listed in AttributesToGet. This return value is equivalent to specifying AttributesToGet without specifying any value for Select.

    If you query or scan a local secondary index and request only attributes that are projected into that index, the operation reads only the index and not the table. If any of the requested attributes are not projected into the local secondary index, DynamoDB fetches each of these attributes from the parent table. This extra fetching incurs additional throughput cost and latency.

    If you query or scan a global secondary index, you can only request attributes that are projected into the index. Global secondary index queries cannot fetch attributes from the parent table.

If neither Select nor AttributesToGet are specified, DynamoDB defaults to ALL_ATTRIBUTES when accessing a table, and ALL_PROJECTED_ATTRIBUTES when accessing an index. You cannot use both Select and AttributesToGet together in a single request, unless the value for Select is SPECIFIC_ATTRIBUTES. (This usage is equivalent to specifying AttributesToGet without any value for Select.)

If you use the ProjectionExpression parameter, then the value for Select can only be SPECIFIC_ATTRIBUTES. Any other value for Select will return an error.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract: The name of the table containing the requested items; or, if you provide IndexName, the name of the table to which that index belongs.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.name: totalSegments
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanInput.html#/c:obj.abstract:
For a parallel Scan request, TotalSegments represents the total number of segments into which the Scan operation will be divided. The value of TotalSegments corresponds to the number of application workers that will perform the parallel scan. For example, if you want to use four application threads to scan a table or an index, specify a TotalSegments value of 4.

The value for TotalSegments must be greater than or equal to 1, and less than or equal to 1000000. If you specify a TotalSegments value of 1, the Scan operation will be sequential rather than parallel.

If you specify TotalSegments, you must also specify Segment.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSESpecification.html.name: enabled
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSESpecification.html.abstract: Indicates whether server-side encryption is done using an AWS managed CMK or an AWS owned CMK. If enabled (true), server-side encryption type is set to KMS and an AWS managed CMK is used (AWS KMS charges apply). If disabled (false) or not specified, server-side encryption is set to AWS owned CMK.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSESpecification.html.name: KMSMasterKeyId
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSESpecification.html.abstract: The AWS KMS customer master key (CMK) that should be used for the AWS KMS encryption. To specify a CMK, use its key ID, Amazon Resource Name (ARN), alias name, or alias ARN. Note that you should only provide this parameter if the key is different from the default DynamoDB customer master key alias/aws/dynamodb.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSESpecification.html.name: SSEType
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSESpecification.html.abstract:
Server-side encryption type. The only supported value is:

  • KMS - Server-side encryption that uses AWS Key Management Service. The key is stored in your account and is managed by AWS KMS (AWS KMS charges apply).

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.name: inaccessibleEncryptionDateTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.abstract: Indicates the time, in UNIX epoch date format, when DynamoDB detected that the table’s AWS KMS key was inaccessible. This attribute will automatically be cleared when DynamoDB detects that the table’s AWS KMS key is accessible again. DynamoDB will initiate the table archival process when table’s AWS KMS key remains inaccessible for more than seven days from this date.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.name: KMSMasterKeyArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.abstract: The AWS KMS customer master key (CMK) ARN used for the AWS KMS encryption.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.name: SSEType
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.abstract:
Server-side encryption type. The only supported value is:

  • KMS - Server-side encryption that uses AWS Key Management Service. The key is stored in your account and is managed by AWS KMS (AWS KMS charges apply).

Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.name: status
Classes/AWSDynamoDBSSEDescription.html#/.abstract:
Represents the current state of server-side encryption. The only supported values are:

  • ENABLED - Server-side encryption is enabled.

  • UPDATING - Server-side encryption is being updated.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: billingModeOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: The billing mode of the restored table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: globalSecondaryIndexOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: List of global secondary indexes for the restored table. The indexes provided should match existing secondary indexes. You can choose to exclude some or all of the indexes at the time of restore.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: localSecondaryIndexOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: List of local secondary indexes for the restored table. The indexes provided should match existing secondary indexes. You can choose to exclude some or all of the indexes at the time of restore.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: provisionedThroughputOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: Provisioned throughput settings for the restored table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: restoreDateTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: Time in the past to restore the table to.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: sourceTableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: Name of the source table that is being restored.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: targetTableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: The name of the new table to which it must be restored to.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.name: useLatestRestorableTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableToPointIn.abstract: Restore the table to the latest possible time. LatestRestorableDateTime is typically 5 minutes before the current time.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: tableDescription
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: The description of the table created from an existing backup.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: backupArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) associated with the backup.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: billingModeOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: The billing mode of the restored table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: globalSecondaryIndexOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: List of global secondary indexes for the restored table. The indexes provided should match existing secondary indexes. You can choose to exclude some or all of the indexes at the time of restore.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: localSecondaryIndexOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: List of local secondary indexes for the restored table. The indexes provided should match existing secondary indexes. You can choose to exclude some or all of the indexes at the time of restore.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: provisionedThroughputOverride
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: Provisioned throughput settings for the restored table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.name: targetTableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreTableFromBacku.abstract: The name of the new table to which the backup must be restored.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.name: restoreDateTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.abstract: Point in time or source backup time.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.name: restoreInProgress
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.abstract: Indicates if a restore is in progress or not.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.name: sourceBackupArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the backup from which the table was restored.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.name: sourceTableArn
Classes/AWSDynamoDBRestoreSummary.html#/.abstract: The ARN of the source table of the backup that is being restored.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.name: create
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.abstract: The parameters required for creating a replica for the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.name: remove
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.abstract: The parameters required for deleting a replica for the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.name: update
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.abstract: The parameters required for updating a replica for the table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaUpdate.html#/c.name: create
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaUpdate.html#/c.abstract: The parameters required for creating a replica on an existing global table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaUpdate.html#/c.name: remove
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaUpdate.html#/c.abstract: The name of the existing replica to be removed.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.name: regionName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.abstract: The Region of the replica to be added.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.name: replicaGlobalSecondaryIndexSettingsUpdate
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.abstract: Represents the settings of a global secondary index for a global table that will be modified.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.name: replicaProvisionedReadCapacityAutoScalingSettingsUpdate
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.abstract: Auto scaling settings for managing a global table replica’s read capacity units.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.name: replicaProvisionedReadCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsUpdate.abstract: The maximum number of strongly consistent reads consumed per second before DynamoDB returns a ThrottlingException. For more information, see Specifying Read and Write Requirements in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaBillingModeSummary
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract: The read/write capacity mode of the replica.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaGlobalSecondaryIndexSettings
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract: Replica global secondary index settings for the global table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaProvisionedReadCapacityAutoScalingSettings
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract: Auto scaling settings for a global table replica’s read capacity units.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaProvisionedReadCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract: The maximum number of strongly consistent reads consumed per second before DynamoDB returns a ThrottlingException. For more information, see Specifying Read and Write Requirements in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaProvisionedWriteCapacityAutoScalingSettings
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract: Auto scaling settings for a global table replica’s write capacity units.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaProvisionedWriteCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract: The maximum number of writes consumed per second before DynamoDB returns a ThrottlingException. For more information, see Specifying Read and Write Requirements in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.name: replicaStatus
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaSettingsDescri.abstract:
The current state of the Region:

  • CREATING - The Region is being created.

  • UPDATING - The Region is being updated.

  • DELETING - The Region is being deleted.

  • ACTIVE - The Region is ready for use.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: indexName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract: The name of the global secondary index. The name must be unique among all other indexes on this table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: provisionedReadCapacityAutoScalingSettingsUpdate
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract: Auto scaling settings for managing a global secondary index replica’s read capacity units.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: provisionedReadCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract: The maximum number of strongly consistent reads consumed per second before DynamoDB returns a ThrottlingException.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: indexName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract: The name of the global secondary index. The name must be unique among all other indexes on this table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: indexStatus
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract:
The current status of the global secondary index:

  • CREATING - The global secondary index is being created.

  • UPDATING - The global secondary index is being updated.

  • DELETING - The global secondary index is being deleted.

  • ACTIVE - The global secondary index is ready for use.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: provisionedReadCapacityAutoScalingSettings
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract: Auto scaling settings for a global secondary index replica’s read capacity units.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.name: provisionedReadCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaGlobalSecondar.abstract: The maximum number of strongly consistent reads consumed per second before DynamoDB returns a ThrottlingException.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicaDescription.ht.abstract: The AWS KMS customer master key (CMK) of the replica that will be used for AWS KMS encryption.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplica.html#/c:objc(.name: regionName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplica.html#/c:objc(.abstract: The Region where the replica needs to be created.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.name: consumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.abstract: The capacity units consumed by the Query operation. The data returned includes the total provisioned throughput consumed, along with statistics for the table and any indexes involved in the operation. ConsumedCapacity is only returned if the ReturnConsumedCapacity parameter was specified. For more information, see Provisioned Throughput in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.name: count
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.abstract:
The number of items in the response.

If you used a QueryFilter in the request, then Count is the number of items returned after the filter was applied, and ScannedCount is the number of matching items before the filter was applied.

If you did not use a filter in the request, then Count and ScannedCount are the same.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.name: items
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.abstract: An array of item attributes that match the query criteria. Each element in this array consists of an attribute name and the value for that attribute.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.name: lastEvaluatedKey
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.abstract:
The primary key of the item where the operation stopped, inclusive of the previous result set. Use this value to start a new operation, excluding this value in the new request.

If LastEvaluatedKey is empty, then the “last page” of results has been processed and there is no more data to be retrieved.

If LastEvaluatedKey is not empty, it does not necessarily mean that there is more data in the result set. The only way to know when you have reached the end of the result set is when LastEvaluatedKey is empty.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.name: scannedCount
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryOutput.html#/c:o.abstract:
The number of items evaluated, before any QueryFilter is applied. A high ScannedCount value with few, or no, Count results indicates an inefficient Query operation. For more information, see Count and ScannedCount in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

If you did not use a filter in the request, then ScannedCount is the same as Count.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: attributesToGet
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use ProjectionExpression instead. For more information, see AttributesToGet in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: conditionalOperator
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use FilterExpression instead. For more information, see ConditionalOperator in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: consistentRead
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
Determines the read consistency model: If set to true, then the operation uses strongly consistent reads; otherwise, the operation uses eventually consistent reads.

Strongly consistent reads are not supported on global secondary indexes. If you query a global secondary index with ConsistentRead set to true, you will receive a ValidationException.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: exclusiveStartKey
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The primary key of the first item that this operation will evaluate. Use the value that was returned for LastEvaluatedKey in the previous operation.

The data type for ExclusiveStartKey must be String, Number, or Binary. No set data types are allowed.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: expressionAttributeNames
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
One or more substitution tokens for attribute names in an expression. The following are some use cases for using ExpressionAttributeNames:

  • To access an attribute whose name conflicts with a DynamoDB reserved word.

  • To create a placeholder for repeating occurrences of an attribute name in an expression.

  • To prevent special characters in an attribute name from being misinterpreted in an expression.

Use the # character in an expression to dereference an attribute name. For example, consider the following attribute name:

  • Percentile

The name of this attribute conflicts with a reserved word, so it cannot be used directly in an expression. (For the complete list of reserved words, see Reserved Words in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide). To work around this, you could specify the following for ExpressionAttributeNames:

  • {"#P":"Percentile"}

You could then use this substitution in an expression, as in this example:

  • #P = :val

Tokens that begin with the : character are expression attribute values, which are placeholders for the actual value at runtime.

For more information on expression attribute names, see Specifying Item Attributes in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: expressionAttributeValues
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
One or more values that can be substituted in an expression.

Use the : (colon) character in an expression to dereference an attribute value. For example, suppose that you wanted to check whether the value of the ProductStatus attribute was one of the following:

Available | Backordered | Discontinued

You would first need to specify ExpressionAttributeValues as follows:

{ ":avail":{"S":"Available"}, ":back":{"S":"Backordered"}, ":disc":{"S":"Discontinued"} }

You could then use these values in an expression, such as this:

ProductStatus IN (:avail, :back, :disc)

For more information on expression attribute values, see Specifying Conditions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: filterExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
A string that contains conditions that DynamoDB applies after the Query operation, but before the data is returned to you. Items that do not satisfy the FilterExpression criteria are not returned.

A FilterExpression does not allow key attributes. You cannot define a filter expression based on a partition key or a sort key.

A FilterExpression is applied after the items have already been read; the process of filtering does not consume any additional read capacity units.

For more information, see Filter Expressions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: indexName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The name of an index to query. This index can be any local secondary index or global secondary index on the table. Note that if you use the IndexName parameter, you must also provide TableName.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: keyConditionExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The condition that specifies the key values for items to be retrieved by the Query action.

The condition must perform an equality test on a single partition key value.

The condition can optionally perform one of several comparison tests on a single sort key value. This allows Query to retrieve one item with a given partition key value and sort key value, or several items that have the same partition key value but different sort key values.

The partition key equality test is required, and must be specified in the following format:

partitionKeyName=:partitionkeyval

If you also want to provide a condition for the sort key, it must be combined using AND with the condition for the sort key. Following is an example, using the = comparison operator for the sort key:

partitionKeyName=:partitionkeyvalANDsortKeyName=:sortkeyval

Valid comparisons for the sort key condition are as follows:

  • sortKeyName=:sortkeyval - true if the sort key value is equal to :sortkeyval.

  • sortKeyName<:sortkeyval - true if the sort key value is less than :sortkeyval.

  • sortKeyName<=:sortkeyval - true if the sort key value is less than or equal to :sortkeyval.

  • sortKeyName>:sortkeyval - true if the sort key value is greater than :sortkeyval.

  • sortKeyName>= :sortkeyval - true if the sort key value is greater than or equal to :sortkeyval.

  • sortKeyNameBETWEEN:sortkeyval1AND:sortkeyval2 - true if the sort key value is greater than or equal to :sortkeyval1, and less than or equal to :sortkeyval2.

  • begins_with (sortKeyName, :sortkeyval) - true if the sort key value begins with a particular operand. (You cannot use this function with a sort key that is of type Number.) Note that the function name begins_with is case-sensitive.

Use the ExpressionAttributeValues parameter to replace tokens such as :partitionval and :sortval with actual values at runtime.

You can optionally use the ExpressionAttributeNames parameter to replace the names of the partition key and sort key with placeholder tokens. This option might be necessary if an attribute name conflicts with a DynamoDB reserved word. For example, the following KeyConditionExpression parameter causes an error because Size is a reserved word:

  • Size = :myval

To work around this, define a placeholder (such a #S) to represent the attribute name Size. KeyConditionExpression then is as follows:

  • #S = :myval

For a list of reserved words, see Reserved Words in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

For more information on ExpressionAttributeNames and ExpressionAttributeValues, see Using Placeholders for Attribute Names and Values in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: keyConditions
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use KeyConditionExpression instead. For more information, see KeyConditions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: limit
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The maximum number of items to evaluate (not necessarily the number of matching items). If DynamoDB processes the number of items up to the limit while processing the results, it stops the operation and returns the matching values up to that point, and a key in LastEvaluatedKey to apply in a subsequent operation, so that you can pick up where you left off. Also, if the processed dataset size exceeds 1 MB before DynamoDB reaches this limit, it stops the operation and returns the matching values up to the limit, and a key in LastEvaluatedKey to apply in a subsequent operation to continue the operation. For more information, see Query and Scan in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: projectionExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
A string that identifies one or more attributes to retrieve from the table. These attributes can include scalars, sets, or elements of a JSON document. The attributes in the expression must be separated by commas.

If no attribute names are specified, then all attributes will be returned. If any of the requested attributes are not found, they will not appear in the result.

For more information, see Accessing Item Attributes in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: queryFilter
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use FilterExpression instead. For more information, see QueryFilter in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: returnConsumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
Determines the level of detail about provisioned throughput consumption that is returned in the response:

  • INDEXES - The response includes the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation, together with ConsumedCapacity for each table and secondary index that was accessed.

    Note that some operations, such as GetItem and BatchGetItem, do not access any indexes at all. In these cases, specifying INDEXES will only return ConsumedCapacity information for table(s).

  • TOTAL - The response includes only the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation.

  • NONE - No ConsumedCapacity details are included in the response.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: scanIndexForward
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
Specifies the order for index traversal: If true (default), the traversal is performed in ascending order; if false, the traversal is performed in descending order.

Items with the same partition key value are stored in sorted order by sort key. If the sort key data type is Number, the results are stored in numeric order. For type String, the results are stored in order of UTF-8 bytes. For type Binary, DynamoDB treats each byte of the binary data as unsigned.

If ScanIndexForward is true, DynamoDB returns the results in the order in which they are stored (by sort key value). This is the default behavior. If ScanIndexForward is false, DynamoDB reads the results in reverse order by sort key value, and then returns the results to the client.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: select
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The attributes to be returned in the result. You can retrieve all item attributes, specific item attributes, the count of matching items, or in the case of an index, some or all of the attributes projected into the index.

  • ALL_ATTRIBUTES - Returns all of the item attributes from the specified table or index. If you query a local secondary index, then for each matching item in the index, DynamoDB fetches the entire item from the parent table. If the index is configured to project all item attributes, then all of the data can be obtained from the local secondary index, and no fetching is required.

  • ALL_PROJECTED_ATTRIBUTES - Allowed only when querying an index. Retrieves all attributes that have been projected into the index. If the index is configured to project all attributes, this return value is equivalent to specifying ALL_ATTRIBUTES.

  • COUNT - Returns the number of matching items, rather than the matching items themselves.

  • SPECIFIC_ATTRIBUTES - Returns only the attributes listed in AttributesToGet. This return value is equivalent to specifying AttributesToGet without specifying any value for Select.

    If you query or scan a local secondary index and request only attributes that are projected into that index, the operation will read only the index and not the table. If any of the requested attributes are not projected into the local secondary index, DynamoDB fetches each of these attributes from the parent table. This extra fetching incurs additional throughput cost and latency.

    If you query or scan a global secondary index, you can only request attributes that are projected into the index. Global secondary index queries cannot fetch attributes from the parent table.

If neither Select nor AttributesToGet are specified, DynamoDB defaults to ALL_ATTRIBUTES when accessing a table, and ALL_PROJECTED_ATTRIBUTES when accessing an index. You cannot use both Select and AttributesToGet together in a single request, unless the value for Select is SPECIFIC_ATTRIBUTES. (This usage is equivalent to specifying AttributesToGet without any value for Select.)

If you use the ProjectionExpression parameter, then the value for Select can only be SPECIFIC_ATTRIBUTES. Any other value for Select will return an error.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBQueryInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The name of the table containing the requested items.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutRequest.html#/c:ob.name: item
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract: A map of attribute name to attribute values, representing the primary key of an item to be processed by PutItem. All of the table’s primary key attributes must be specified, and their data types must match those of the table’s key schema. If any attributes are present in the item that are part of an index key schema for the table, their types must match the index key schema.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemOutput.html#/c.name: attributes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemOutput.html#/c.abstract: The attribute values as they appeared before the PutItem operation, but only if ReturnValues is specified as ALL_OLD in the request. Each element consists of an attribute name and an attribute value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemOutput.html#/c.name: consumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemOutput.html#/c.abstract: The capacity units consumed by the PutItem operation. The data returned includes the total provisioned throughput consumed, along with statistics for the table and any indexes involved in the operation. ConsumedCapacity is only returned if the ReturnConsumedCapacity parameter was specified. For more information, see Read/Write Capacity Mode in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemOutput.html#/c.name: itemCollectionMetrics
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemOutput.html#/c.abstract:
Information about item collections, if any, that were affected by the PutItem operation. ItemCollectionMetrics is only returned if the ReturnItemCollectionMetrics parameter was specified. If the table does not have any local secondary indexes, this information is not returned in the response.

Each ItemCollectionMetrics element consists of:

  • ItemCollectionKey - The partition key value of the item collection. This is the same as the partition key value of the item itself.

  • SizeEstimateRangeGB - An estimate of item collection size, in gigabytes. This value is a two-element array containing a lower bound and an upper bound for the estimate. The estimate includes the size of all the items in the table, plus the size of all attributes projected into all of the local secondary indexes on that table. Use this estimate to measure whether a local secondary index is approaching its size limit.

    The estimate is subject to change over time; therefore, do not rely on the precision or accuracy of the estimate.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: conditionExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract:
A condition that must be satisfied in order for a conditional PutItem operation to succeed.

An expression can contain any of the following:

  • Functions: attribute_exists | attribute_not_exists | attribute_type | contains | begins_with | size

    These function names are case-sensitive.

  • Comparison operators: = | <> | < | > | <= | >= | BETWEEN | IN

  • Logical operators: AND | OR | NOT

For more information on condition expressions, see Condition Expressions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: conditionalOperator
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use ConditionExpression instead. For more information, see ConditionalOperator in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: expected
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract: This is a legacy parameter. Use ConditionExpression instead. For more information, see Expected in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: expressionAttributeNames
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract:
One or more substitution tokens for attribute names in an expression. The following are some use cases for using ExpressionAttributeNames:

  • To access an attribute whose name conflicts with a DynamoDB reserved word.

  • To create a placeholder for repeating occurrences of an attribute name in an expression.

  • To prevent special characters in an attribute name from being misinterpreted in an expression.

Use the # character in an expression to dereference an attribute name. For example, consider the following attribute name:

  • Percentile

The name of this attribute conflicts with a reserved word, so it cannot be used directly in an expression. (For the complete list of reserved words, see Reserved Words in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide). To work around this, you could specify the following for ExpressionAttributeNames:

  • {"#P":"Percentile"}

You could then use this substitution in an expression, as in this example:

  • #P = :val

Tokens that begin with the : character are expression attribute values, which are placeholders for the actual value at runtime.

For more information on expression attribute names, see Specifying Item Attributes in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: expressionAttributeValues
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract:
One or more values that can be substituted in an expression.

Use the : (colon) character in an expression to dereference an attribute value. For example, suppose that you wanted to check whether the value of the ProductStatus attribute was one of the following:

Available | Backordered | Discontinued

You would first need to specify ExpressionAttributeValues as follows:

{ ":avail":{"S":"Available"}, ":back":{"S":"Backordered"}, ":disc":{"S":"Discontinued"} }

You could then use these values in an expression, such as this:

ProductStatus IN (:avail, :back, :disc)

For more information on expression attribute values, see Condition Expressions in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: item
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract:
A map of attribute name/value pairs, one for each attribute. Only the primary key attributes are required; you can optionally provide other attribute name-value pairs for the item.

You must provide all of the attributes for the primary key. For example, with a simple primary key, you only need to provide a value for the partition key. For a composite primary key, you must provide both values for both the partition key and the sort key.

If you specify any attributes that are part of an index key, then the data types for those attributes must match those of the schema in the table’s attribute definition.

For more information about primary keys, see Primary Key in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Each element in the Item map is an AttributeValue object.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: returnConsumedCapacity
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract:
Determines the level of detail about provisioned throughput consumption that is returned in the response:

  • INDEXES - The response includes the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation, together with ConsumedCapacity for each table and secondary index that was accessed.

    Note that some operations, such as GetItem and BatchGetItem, do not access any indexes at all. In these cases, specifying INDEXES will only return ConsumedCapacity information for table(s).

  • TOTAL - The response includes only the aggregate ConsumedCapacity for the operation.

  • NONE - No ConsumedCapacity details are included in the response.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: returnItemCollectionMetrics
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract: Determines whether item collection metrics are returned. If set to SIZE, the response includes statistics about item collections, if any, that were modified during the operation are returned in the response. If set to NONE (the default), no statistics are returned.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: returnValues
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract:
Use ReturnValues if you want to get the item attributes as they appeared before they were updated with the PutItem request. For PutItem, the valid values are:

  • NONE - If ReturnValues is not specified, or if its value is NONE, then nothing is returned. (This setting is the default for ReturnValues.)

  • ALL_OLD - If PutItem overwrote an attribute name-value pair, then the content of the old item is returned.

The ReturnValues parameter is used by several DynamoDB operations; however, PutItem does not recognize any values other than NONE or ALL_OLD.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPutItemInput.html#/c:.abstract: The name of the table to contain the item.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: conditionExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: A condition that must be satisfied in order for a conditional update to succeed.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: expressionAttributeNames
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: One or more substitution tokens for attribute names in an expression.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: expressionAttributeValues
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: One or more values that can be substituted in an expression.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: item
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: A map of attribute name to attribute values, representing the primary key of the item to be written by PutItem. All of the table’s primary key attributes must be specified, and their data types must match those of the table’s key schema. If any attributes are present in the item that are part of an index key schema for the table, their types must match the index key schema.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: returnValuesOnConditionCheckFailure
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: Use ReturnValuesOnConditionCheckFailure to get the item attributes if the Put condition fails. For ReturnValuesOnConditionCheckFailure, the valid values are: NONE and ALL_OLD.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.name: tableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPut.html#/c:objc(cs)A.abstract: Name of the table in which to write the item.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.name: readCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.abstract: Replica-specific read capacity units. If not specified, uses the source table’s read capacity settings.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.name: lastDecreaseDateTime
Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.abstract: The date and time of the last provisioned throughput decrease for this table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.name: readCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.abstract: The maximum number of strongly consistent reads consumed per second before DynamoDB returns a ThrottlingException. Eventually consistent reads require less effort than strongly consistent reads, so a setting of 50 ReadCapacityUnits per second provides 100 eventually consistent ReadCapacityUnits per second.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.name: writeCapacityUnits

If read/write capacity mode is PAY_PER_REQUEST the value is set to 0.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.name: writeCapacityUnits
Classes/AWSDynamoDBProvisionedThroughput.abstract:

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProjection.html#/c:ob.name: nonKeyAttributes
Classes/AWSDynamoDBProjection.html#/c:ob.abstract:
Represents the non-key attribute names which will be projected into the index.

For local secondary indexes, the total count of NonKeyAttributes summed across all of the local secondary indexes, must not exceed 20. If you project the same attribute into two different indexes, this counts as two distinct attributes when determining the total.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBProjection.html#/c:ob.name: projectionType
Classes/AWSDynamoDBProjection.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The set of attributes that are projected into the index:

  • KEYS_ONLY - Only the index and primary keys are projected into the index.

  • INCLUDE - Only the specified table attributes are projected into the index. The list of projected attributes is in NonKeyAttributes.

  • ALL - All of the table attributes are projected into the index.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPointInTimeRecoverySp.name: pointInTimeRecoveryEnabled

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPointInTimeRecoveryDe.name: earliestRestorableDateTime

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPointInTimeRecoveryDe.name: latestRestorableDateTime

Classes/AWSDynamoDBPointInTimeRecoveryDe.name: pointInTimeRecoveryStatus
Classes/AWSDynamoDBPointInTimeRecoveryDe.abstract:
The current state of point in time recovery:

  • ENABLING - Point in time recovery is being enabled.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBLocalSecondaryIndexIn.name: keySchema
Classes/AWSDynamoDBLocalSecondaryIndexIn.abstract:
The complete key schema for a local secondary index, which consists of one or more pairs of attribute names and key types:

  • HASH - partition key

  • RANGE - sort key

The partition key of an item is also known as its hash attribute. The term “hash attribute” derives from DynamoDB’s usage of an internal hash function to evenly distribute data items across partitions, based on their partition key values.

The sort key of an item is also known as its range attribute. The term “range attribute” derives from the way DynamoDB stores items with the same partition key physically close together, in sorted order by the sort key value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTagsOfResourceOut.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTagsOfResourceOut.abstract: If this value is returned, there are additional results to be displayed. To retrieve them, call ListTagsOfResource again, with NextToken set to this value.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesOutput.html.name: lastEvaluatedTableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesOutput.html.abstract:
The name of the last table in the current page of results. Use this value as the ExclusiveStartTableName in a new request to obtain the next page of results, until all the table names are returned.

If you do not receive a LastEvaluatedTableName value in the response, this means that there are no more table names to be retrieved.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesOutput.html.name: tableNames
Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesOutput.html.abstract:
The names of the tables associated with the current account at the current endpoint. The maximum size of this array is 100.

If LastEvaluatedTableName also appears in the output, you can use this value as the ExclusiveStartTableName parameter in a subsequent ListTables request and obtain the next page of results.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesInput.html#.name: exclusiveStartTableName
Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesInput.html#.abstract: The first table name that this operation will evaluate. Use the value that was returned for LastEvaluatedTableName in a previous operation, so that you can obtain the next page of results.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesInput.html#.name: limit
Classes/AWSDynamoDBListTablesInput.html#.abstract: A maximum number of table names to return. If this parameter is not specified, the limit is 100.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListContributorInsigh.name: nextToken

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListContributorInsigh.name: maxResults

Classes/AWSDynamoDBListContributorInsigh.name: nextToken
