  • A new replica to be added to an existing global table.

  • New parameters for an existing replica.

  • An existing replica to be removed from an existing global table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.name: AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdate
Classes/AWSDynamoDBReplicationGroupUpdat.abstract:
Represents one of the following:

  • A new replica to be added to an existing regional table or global table. This request invokes the CreateTableReplica action in the destination Region.

  • New parameters for an existing replica. This request invokes the UpdateTable action in the destination Region.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBStreamSpecification.h.abstract: Represents the DynamoDB Streams configuration for a table in DynamoDB.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTableAutoScalingDescr.abstract: Represents the auto scaling configuration for a global table.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTag.html.name: AWSDynamoDBTag
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTag.html.abstract:
Describes a tag. A tag is a key-value pair. You can add up to 50 tags to a single DynamoDB table.

AWS-assigned tag names and values are automatically assigned the aws: prefix, which the user cannot assign. AWS-assigned tag names do not count towards the tag limit of 50. User-assigned tag names have the prefix user: in the Cost Allocation Report. You cannot backdate the application of a tag.

For an overview on tagging DynamoDB resources, see Tagging for DynamoDB in the Amazon DynamoDB Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveDescription.name: AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveDescription

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveSpecificati.name: AWSDynamoDBTimeToLiveSpecification

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItem.html.name: AWSDynamoDBTransactGetItem

Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItem.htm.name: AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItem
Classes/AWSDynamoDBTransactWriteItem.htm.abstract: A list of requests that can perform update, put, delete, or check operations on multiple items in one or more tables atomically.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html.name: AWSDynamoDBUpdate
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdate.html.abstract: Represents a request to perform an UpdateItem operation.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdateGlobalSecondary.name: AWSDynamoDBUpdateGlobalSecondaryIndexAction
Classes/AWSDynamoDBUpdateGlobalSecondary.abstract: Represents the new provisioned throughput settings to be applied to a global secondary index.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBWriteRequest.html.name: AWSDynamoDBWriteRequest
Classes/AWSDynamoDBWriteRequest.html.abstract: Represents an operation to perform - either DeleteItem or PutItem. You can only request one of these operations, not both, in a single WriteRequest. If you do need to perform both of these operations, you need to provide two separate WriteRequest objects.

Classes.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSDynamoDBObjec.name: AWSDynamoDBObjectModel
Classes.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSDynamoDBObjec.abstract: A base class for all objects mapped to an Amazon DynamoDB table row. They need to inherit from this class.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBObjectMapper.html.name: AWSDynamoDBObjectMapper
Classes/AWSDynamoDBObjectMapper.html.abstract: Object mapper for domain-object interaction with DynamoDB.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBObjectMapperConfigura.name: AWSDynamoDBObjectMapperConfiguration
Classes/AWSDynamoDBObjectMapperConfigura.abstract: Immutable configuration object for service call behavior. An instance of this configuration is supplied to every DynamoDBMapper at construction. New instances can be given to the mapper object on individual save, load, and remove operations to override the defaults.

Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanExpression.html.name: AWSDynamoDBScanExpression
Classes/AWSDynamoDBScanExpression.html.abstract: Options for filtering results from a scan operation. For example, callers can specify filter conditions so that only objects whose attributes match different conditions are returned (see ComparisonOperator for more information on the available comparison types).

Classes/AWSDynamoDB.html.name: AWSDynamoDB
Classes/AWSDynamoDB.html.abstract:
Amazon DynamoDB

Amazon DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database service that provides fast and predictable performance with seamless scalability. DynamoDB lets you offload the administrative burdens of operating and scaling a distributed database, so that you don’t have to worry about hardware provisioning, setup and configuration, replication, software patching, or cluster scaling.

With DynamoDB, you can create database tables that can store and retrieve any amount of data, and serve any level of request traffic. You can scale up or scale down your tables’ throughput capacity without downtime or performance degradation, and use the AWS Management Console to monitor resource utilization and performance metrics.

DynamoDB automatically spreads the data and traffic for your tables over a sufficient number of servers to handle your throughput and storage requirements, while maintaining consistent and fast performance. All of your data is stored on solid state disks (SSDs) and automatically replicated across multiple Availability Zones in an AWS region, providing built-in high availability and data durability.
